conclusion: Factors to consider: direction of A's movement, arrangement of blocks, effects of collisions and deflections.
A is moving from the lower right towards the group of blocks.
The speed and power of A will determine how far it can travel and how it interacts with the blocks.
Blocks are arranged in a somewhat scattered manner.
The closest blocks to A's initial path are the red block and the green block near the center.
A will likely first collide with the red block, as it is directly in its path.
The collision will depend on A's speed and the mass of the red block.
After hitting the red block, A may be deflected.
Depending on the angle and force of the collision, A could move towards the green block near the red block or continue towards the orange blocks.
If A continues with sufficient speed, it might collide with the orange blocks next.
The sequence of collisions will depend on the deflection angles and the remaining speed of A after each collision.
A will eventually stop after losing enough energy from collisions.
The final stopping point will be determined by the cumulative effects of all collisions and the friction of the surface.
A will collide with the red block first.
Depending on the deflection, A might hit the green block near the red block or the orange blocks.
A will stop after losing energy from collisions, likely near the last block it hits.

A will first collide with the red block, then potentially hit the green block near the red block or the orange blocks, and will eventually stop near the last block it collides with, depending on the energy and deflection angles.
